statement:
If $S$ is a finite set of variable symbols, then the number of monomials
of degree $n$ constructed from these symbols is ${n + m - 1 \choose n}$,
where $m$ is the cardinality of $S$.

The proof proceeds by inducion on the cardinality of $S$. If $S$ has but
one element, then there is but one monomial of degree $n$, namely the
sole element of $S$ raised to the $n$-th power. Since
${n + 1 - 1 \choose n} = 1$, the conclusion holds when $m = 1$.

Suppose, then, that the result holds whenver $m < M$ for some $M$. Let
$S$ be a set with exactly $M$ elements and let $x$ be an element of $S$.
A monomial of degree $n$ constructed from elements of $S$ can be
expressed as the product of a power of $x$ and a monomial constructed
from the elements of $S \setminus
\{x\}$. By the induction hypothesis, the number of monomials of degree
$k$ constructed from elements of $S \setminus \{x\}$ is
${k + M - 2 \choose k}$. Summing over the possible powers to which $x$
may be raised, the number of monomials of degree $n$ constructed from
the elements of $S$ is as follows:
$$\sum_{k=0}^n {k + M - 2 \choose k} = {k + M - 1 \choose k}$$

If $S$ is an infinite set of variable symbols, then the number of
monomials of degree $n$ constructed from these symbols equals the
cardinality of $S$.
